Spy"/> Microsoft CEO Steve Ballmer has said that the Xbox 360 is not a games console. He told USA Today that its multimedia capabilities and Kinect support makes it an entertainment device. Xbox isn't a gaming console. Xbox is a family entertainment centre. It's a place to socialise, he said. "It's a place to watch TV. We have Hulu coming. It's the only system where you are the controller. Your voice, your gestures, your body."

Google co-founder Larry Page will replace Eric Schmidt and take over as Chief Executive Officer in April. Eric Schmidt , 55, who became CEO in 2001, will assume the role of Executive Chairman, focusing externally on deals, partnerships, customers and broader business relationships, government outreach and technology thought leadership, according to the official Google blog spot. View result Eric Schmidt would continue to act as an advisor to Page and co-founder Sergey Brin . "Page will take charge of Google's day-to-day operations as Chief Executive Officer starting April 4. Sergey Brin will focus on strategic projects, in particular working on new products, Eric Schmidt said in the blog spot. Philadelphia has alternated wins and losses in its last six games after losing nine of 10. The Sixers, who opened the season 10-0 at the First Union Center, are 1-7 in their last eight home games. This is not the team we thought we were going to have, Sixers coach Larry David West said, referring to injuries that have hampered the team. Philadelphia, which trailed by 18 in the second quarter, closed to 50-47 following a three-point play by Allen Iverson early in the third.

Bloomberg Businessweek has an interesting report citing those infamous "people in the know," claiming that Microsoft CEO Steve Ballmer is readying a management shakeup which will place more senior product executives who have a strong engineering background. The thinking: Microsoft needs more technology-minded top dogs to help the company compete( or at least to provide the outward impression that engineering prowess still matters in Redmond). she and Debbie Wasserman Schultz recalled dinners and family vacations they'd taken with Gabrielle Giffords . That's when Gabrielle Giffords squeezed Kirsten Gillibrand 's hand and her right eye started to flicker, before finally opening wide. Debbie Wasserman Schultz says, it was like she was trying to will her eyes open, adding: "It felt like we were watching a miracle."
